class.name: MultiMeshBullets2D
class.brief_description: This class is only meant to be inherited by other C++ classes. Never use this by its own. Always use the [BulletFactory2D], that's the only proper way.

method.name: all_bullets_get_attachments
method.description: Get the attachments of all bullets in the specified range. Returns an array of [BulletAttachment2D], which can be null if a bullet doesn't have an attachment.

method.name: all_bullets_get_curves_data
method.description: Get the curves data of all bullets in the specified range. Returns an array of [BulletCurvesData2D], which can be null if a bullet doesn't have curves data assigned.

method.name: all_bullets_get_direction
method.description: Get the direction of all bullets in the specified range. Returns an array of [Vector2] directions.

method.name: all_bullets_get_speed_data
method.description: Get the speed data of all bullets in the specified range. Returns an array of [BulletSpeedData2D].

method.name: all_bullets_get_texture_rotation_degrees
method.description: Get the texture rotation in degrees of all bullets in the specified range. Returns an array of floats representing the rotation in degrees.

method.name: all_bullets_get_texture_rotation_radians
method.description: Get the texture rotation in radians of all bullets in the specified range. Returns an array of floats representing the rotation in radians.

method.name: all_bullets_get_transforms
method.description: Get the transforms of all bullets in the specified range. Returns an array of [Transform2D].

method.name: all_bullets_remove_movement_pattern
method.description: Removes the movement pattern from all bullets in the specified range, making them lose any [Path2D] or [Curve2D] drawn pattern they had and move solely based on their direction and speed data.

method.name: all_bullets_set_attachment
method.description: Spawns the same attachment to all bullets in the specified range. An attachment is a [BulletAttachment2D] that can contain a [Node2D] with particles, lights, etc... that will be attached to the bullet and follow it around. You can use the [BulletAttachment2D] properties to control how the attachment behaves and is positioned relative to the bullet.

method.name: all_bullets_set_attachment_to_null
method.description:
Removes the attachments of all bullets in the specified range by setting them to null. Returns an array of the removed [BulletAttachment2D] attachments, which can be useful if you want to reuse them as they are not freed, just detached from the bullets.
Warning: You have to take care of the returned attachments yourself.

method.name: all_bullets_set_curves_data
method.description: Sets the same curves data to all bullets in the specified range. Curves data is a [BulletCurvesData2D] resource that can contain multiple curves used to control different aspects of the bullet's behavior over time, such as movement speed, rotation speed, direction adjustment, etc...

method.name: all_bullets_set_direction
method.description: Sets the direction of all bullets in the specified range to a new direction. The direction gets normalized automatically.

method.name: all_bullets_set_direction_towards_node2d
method.description: Sets the direction of all bullets in the specified range towards a target [Node2D]. The direction gets normalized automatically.

method.name: all_bullets_set_direction_towards_position
method.description: Sets the direction of all bullets in the specified range towards a target global position. The direction gets normalized automatically.

method.name: all_bullets_set_movement_pattern_from_curve
method.description:
Sets a [Curve2D] drawn movement pattern to all bullets in the specified range. The bullets will follow the shape of the curve as they move.
If [code]face_movement_direction[/code] is set to true, the bullets will also rotate to face the direction they are moving along the curve.
If [code]repeat_pattern[/code] is set to true, once a bullet reaches the end of the curve pattern it will start again from the beginning, creating a loop. If false, once a bullet reaches the end of the curve pattern it will stop following it and continue moving in a straight line based on its current direction and speed.

method.name: all_bullets_set_movement_pattern_from_path
method.description:
Sets a [Path2D] drawn movement pattern to all bullets in the specified range. The bullets will follow the shape of the path as they move.
If [code]face_movement_direction[/code] is set to true, the bullets will also rotate to face the direction they are moving along the path.
If [code]repeat_pattern[/code] is set to true, once a bullet reaches the end of the path pattern it will start again from the beginning, creating a loop. If false, once a bullet reaches the end of the path pattern it will stop following it and continue moving in a straight line based on its current direction and speed.

method.name: all_bullets_set_speed_data
method.description: Sets the same speed data to all bullets in the specified range. Speed data is a [BulletSpeedData2D] resource that can contain multiple properties used to control different aspects of the bullet's speed behavior, such as initial speed, acceleration, deceleration, max speed, etc...

method.name: all_bullets_set_texture_rotation_degrees
method.description: Sets the same texture rotation in degrees to all bullets in the specified range.

method.name: all_bullets_set_texture_rotation_radians
method.description: Sets the same texture rotation in radians to all bullets in the specified range.

method.name: all_bullets_set_texture_rotation_towards_node2d
method.description: Sets the texture rotation of all bullets in the specified range towards a target [Node2D]. The rotation will be set so that the bullet's texture faces towards the target node.

method.name: all_bullets_set_texture_rotation_towards_position
method.description: Sets the texture rotation of all bullets in the specified range towards a target global position. The rotation will be set so that the bullet's texture faces towards the target position.

method.name: all_bullets_set_transforms
method.description:
Sets the same transform to all bullets in the specified range. A transform is a [Transform2D] that contains the bullet's position, rotation and scale. If you want to set them separately, use [method all_bullets_set_direction], [method all_bullets_set_texture_rotation_degrees], [method all_bullets_set_texture_rotation_radians] or [method all_bullets_set_speed_data].
If [code]set_direction_based_on_transform[/code] is set to true, the direction of the bullets will be set based on the rotation of the provided transform. If false, the transform's rotation will be ignored and only its position and scale will be applied to the bullets, keeping their original direction. The direction gets normalized automatically.

method.name: bullet_disable_attachment
method.description: Disables the attachment of a specific bullet by calling its virtual function [method BulletAttachment2D.on_bullet_disable].

method.name: bullet_enable_attachment
method.description: Enables the attachment of a specific bullet by calling its virtual function [method BulletAttachment2D.on_bullet_enable].

method.name: bullet_free_attachment
method.description:
Frees the attachment of a specific bullet, removing it from the scene tree and freeing the memory it occupies. Use this if you want to permanently remove an attachment from a bullet and free its resources, instead of just disabling it with [method bullet_disable_attachment].
Warning: Once you free an attachment, you can't reuse it anymore.

method.name: bullet_get_attachment
method.description: Gets the attachment of a specific bullet. Returns a [BulletAttachment2D], which can be null if the bullet doesn't have an attachment.

method.name: bullet_get_curves_data
method.description: Gets the curves data of a specific bullet. Returns a [BulletCurvesData2D], which can be null if the bullet doesn't have curves data assigned. Curves data is a [BulletCurvesData2D] resource that can contain multiple curves used to control different aspects of the bullet's behavior over time, such as movement speed, rotation speed, direction adjustment, etc... Note: If you want to set or get the curves data of multiple bullets at once, use [method all_bullets_set_curves_data] or [method all_bullets_get_curves_data].

method.name: bullet_set_attachment
method.description: Spawns an attachment to a specific bullet. An attachment is a [BulletAttachment2D] that can contain a [Node2D] with particles, lights, etc... that will be attached to the bullet and follow it around.

method.name: bullet_set_attachment_to_null
method.description:
Removes the attachment of a specific bullet by setting it to null. Returns the removed [BulletAttachment2D] attachment, which can be useful if you want to reuse it as it is not freed, just detached from the bullet.
A cool trick you can do is, when a bullet collides or you want to disable it manually (with [method disable_bullet]) but keep its attachment active for a bit longer (for example, to let some particles or lights finish their effect), you can call this function to detach the attachment from the bullet and keep it on the scene.
Warning: You have to take care of the returned attachment yourself.

method.name: bullet_set_curves_data
method.description:
Sets the curves data of a specific bullet. Curves data is a [BulletCurvesData2D] resource that can contain multiple curves used to control different aspects of the bullet's behavior over time, such as movement speed, rotation speed, direction adjustment, etc...
Note: If you want to set or get the curves data of multiple bullets at once, use [method all_bullets_set_curves_data] or [method all_bullets_get_curves_data].

method.name: disable_bullet
method.description: Disable a specific bullet from the multimesh

method.name: enable_bullet
method.description:
Activate a specific bullet from the multimesh, making it active and visible on screen.
You can also provide a [code]collision_amount[/code], which is how many times this bullet can collide before it gets disabled.
If you provide 0, a negative value or a value greater than [member bullet_max_collision_count], then the bullet will be able to collide [member bullet_max_collision_count] times before it gets disabled.
It's valid to set it to a value that is less than [member bullet_max_collision_count].

method.name: get_all_bullets_status
method.description: Get the status of all bullets inside the multimesh - whether they are enabled (active and visible on screen) or disabled (inactive and invisible)

method.name: get_amount_bullets
method.description: Get the amount of bullets inside the multimesh

method.name: get_bullet_direction
method.description: Get the direction of a specific bullet. Returns a [Vector2] direction.

method.name: get_bullet_movement_pattern_curve
method.description: Get the movement pattern curve of a specific bullet.

method.name: get_bullet_speed_data
method.description: Get the speed data of a specific bullet. Returns a [BulletSpeedData2D] resource.

method.name: get_bullet_texture_rotation_degrees
method.description: Get the texture rotation in degrees of a specific bullet. Returns a float representing the rotation in degrees.

method.name: get_bullet_texture_rotation_radians
method.description: Get the texture rotation in radians of a specific bullet. Returns a float representing the rotation in radians.

method.name: get_bullet_transform
method.description: Get the transform of a specific bullet. Returns a [Transform2D] containing the bullet's position, rotation and scale.

method.name: get_inherited_velocity_offset
method.description: Get the inherited velocity offset. This is the velocity that gets added to the bullets when they are spawned. This is useful for creating effects like a machine gun that inherits the velocity of the player character, so that the bullets shoot out with more speed if the player is moving forward, and with less speed if the player is moving backward or standing still. Note: If you want to set a custom inherited velocity offset, you can use [method set_inherited_velocity_offset].

method.name: get_textures
method.description: Get all textures that are currently being used to render the bullets with animation.

method.name: has_bullet_movement_pattern
method.description: Check if a specific bullet has a movement pattern assigned to it, either from a [Path2D] or a [Curve2D]. Returns true if the bullet has a movement pattern, false if it doesn't. Note: A bullet can have its movement pattern removed by using [method remove_bullet_movement_pattern] or [method all_bullets_remove_movement_pattern].

method.name: is_bullet_status_enabled
method.description: Check the status of a specific bullet - whether it is enabled (active and visible on screen) or disabled (inactive and invisible)

method.name: multimesh_attach_time_based_function
method.description:
Attaches a callable that gets executed after a certain amount of time.
[code]time[/code] - the time in seconds after which the callable will be executed. [code]callable[/code] - the callable that will be executed. It can be a lambda, a function or a method from another object. [code]repeat[/code] - if set to true, then the callable will be executed every [code]time[/code] seconds. [code]execute_only_if_multimesh_is_active[/code] - if set to [code]true[/code], then the callable will only be executed if the multimesh is active in the scene tree (if it has at least a single bullet that has not yet been disabled). If you wish to execute the callable regardless of the multimesh being active or not (even when in object pool), then set this parameter to [code]false[/code]. Note: For this to take effect ensure that the [member is_multimesh_auto_pooling_enabled] property is set to false - this is because auto pooling clears any callables in order to re-use the multimesh later completely reset.
If you want to be able to detach the callable, then make sure that it is clearly declared outside as a variable or you could even use a normal Godot function.
Callables that execute bullet related functions have no need of using call_deferred(), since all attached callables are executed at the end of the frame by default for safety.

method.name: multimesh_detach_all_time_based_functions
method.description: Detaches all time based functions that were previously attached.

method.name: multimesh_detach_time_based_function
method.description: Detaches a specific time based callable. This will work as long as the callable you are trying to detach was previously saved in a variable or defined as a normal Godot function.

method.name: remove_bullet_movement_pattern
method.description: Removes the movement pattern from a specific bullet, making it lose any [Path2D] or [Curve2D] drawn pattern it had and move solely based on its direction and speed data. Note: If you want to remove the movement pattern from multiple bullets at once, use [method all_bullets_remove_movement_pattern]. Note: A bullet can have a movement pattern assigned by using [method set_bullet_movement_pattern_from_curve] or [method set_bullet_movement_pattern_from_path].

method.name: set_bullet_direction
method.description: Set the direction of a specific bullet to a new direction. The direction gets normalized automatically.

method.name: set_bullet_direction_towards_node2d
method.description: Set the direction of a specific bullet towards a target [Node2D]. The direction gets normalized automatically.

method.name: set_bullet_direction_towards_position
method.description: Set the direction of a specific bullet towards a target global position. The direction gets normalized automatically.

method.name: set_bullet_movement_pattern_from_curve
method.description:
Set a [Curve2D] drawn movement pattern to a specific bullet. The bullet will follow the shape of the curve as it moves.
If [code]face_movement_direction[/code] is set to true, the bullet will also rotate to face the direction it is moving along the curve.
If [code]repeat_pattern[/code] is set to true, once the bullet reaches the end of the curve pattern it will start again from the beginning, creating a loop. If false, once the bullet reaches the end of the curve pattern it will stop following it and continue moving in a straight line based on its current direction and speed. Note: If you want to set a movement pattern from a curve to multiple bullets at once, use [method all_bullets_set_movement_pattern_from_curve]. Note: A bullet can have its movement pattern removed by using [method remove_bullet_movement_pattern] or [method all_bullets_remove_movement_pattern]. Note: A bullet can only have one movement pattern at a time, so if you set a new movement pattern to a bullet that already has one, it will replace the previous one.

method.name: set_bullet_movement_pattern_from_path
method.description:
Set a [Path2D] drawn movement pattern to a specific bullet. The bullet will follow the shape of the path as it moves.
If [code]face_movement_direction[/code] is set to true, the bullet will also rotate to face the direction it is moving along the path.
If [code]repeat_pattern[/code] is set to true, once the bullet reaches the end of the path pattern it will start again from the beginning, creating a loop. If false, once the bullet reaches the end of the path pattern it will stop following it and continue moving in a straight line based on its current direction and speed. Note: If you want to set a movement pattern from a path to multiple bullets at once, use [method all_bullets_set_movement_pattern_from_path]. Note: A bullet can have its movement pattern removed by using [method remove_bullet_movement_pattern] or [method all_bullets_remove_movement_pattern]. Note: A bullet can only have one movement pattern at a time, so if you set a new movement pattern to a bullet that already has one, it will replace the previous one. Note: The [Path2D] used for setting a movement pattern doesn't need to be in the scene tree, since only its curve is used for the bullets movement. Warning: If you are using a [Path2D] that is in the scene tree and you modify its curve after setting it as a movement pattern for a bullet, it may cause unexpected behavior in the bullet's movement. This is because the bullet's movement pattern is based on the curve data of the [Path2D], and modifying it while it's being used can lead to inconsistencies. It's recommended to use a [Path2D] that is not in the scene tree or to avoid modifying its curve after assigning it as a movement pattern to bullets.

method.name: set_bullet_speed_data
method.description: Set the speed data of a specific bullet.

method.name: set_bullet_texture_rotation_degrees
method.description: Set the texture rotation in degrees of a specific bullet.

method.name: set_bullet_texture_rotation_radians
method.description: Set the texture rotation in radians of a specific bullet.

method.name: set_bullet_texture_rotation_towards_node2d
method.description: Set the texture rotation of a specific bullet towards a target [Node2D]. The rotation will be set so that the bullet's texture faces towards the target node.

method.name: set_bullet_texture_rotation_towards_position
method.description: Set the texture rotation of a specific bullet towards a target global position. The rotation will be set so that the bullet's texture faces towards the target position.

method.name: set_bullet_transform
method.description: Set the transform of a specific bullet.

method.name: set_bullets_current_collision_count
method.description:
Set the current collision count for multiple bullets at once by providing an array of integers, where each integer represents the current collision count for a bullet. The index of each integer in the array corresponds to the bullet index it is meant to set the collision count for.
For example, if you have 3 bullets and you want to set their current collision counts to 1, 2 and 3 respectively, you would call this function with an array like [1, 2, 3].

method.name: set_inherited_velocity_offset
method.description: Sets a custom inherited velocity offset. This is the velocity that gets added to the bullets when they are spawned. This is useful for creating effects like a machine gun that inherits the velocity of the player character, so that the bullets shoot out with more speed if the player is moving forward, and with less speed if the player is moving backward or standing still.

method.name: set_textures
method.description: Sets the textures used to render the bullets with animation. You can provide an array of textures to create a frame by frame animation effect on the bullets. The [code]new_change_texture_times[/code] parameter is an array of floats that specifies how many seconds to wait before changing to the next texture in the [code]new_textures[/code] array. The index of each float in the [code]new_change_texture_times[/code] array corresponds to the texture index it is meant to set the change time for.

members.member: How many times a bullet can collide before it gets disabled. If you set to 0, then the bullet will NEVER get disabled due to collisions.

An array of integers representing the current collision count for each bullet. The index of each integer in the array corresponds to the bullet index it is meant to represent.
For example, if you have 3 bullets and their current collision counts are 1, 2 and 3 respectively, then this array would be [1, 2, 3].
You can use this property to keep track of how many times each bullet has collided, and you can also set it to update the collision counts as needed.
You can edit the custom bullets data that the bullets multimesh was spawned with. Use this to set damage data or anything else you want to store in a resource for your bullets to use.
The elapsed time used for the bullets' curves. This is the time that gets passed to the curves assigned to the bullets, you can manipulate it freely.

Whether the attachments auto pooling is enabled or not.
When enabled, the attachments will automatically get pushed to the object pool when the bullets get disabled. When disabled, the attachments will automatically get freed from the scene tree upon collision.

If you set to true, then the lifetime will be ignored and bullets will never be destroyed.
Warning: If you don't implement "collision walls" or anything else to intercept/collide with the bullets, then they will truly live forever in your memory and you will experience lag.

Whether the multimesh auto pooling is enabled or not.
When enabled, the multimesh will automatically get pushed to the object pool when all bullets are disabled. When disabled, you are the one responsible for re-using the multimesh or clearing any time based callables that you might have attached with [member attach_time_based_function].
If you are going to save your multimesh bullets in an array, then it's probably best to disable auto pooling and manage the instances yourself.

A shared [BulletCurvesData2D] resource that can be assigned to all bullets in the multimesh. This is useful for saving memory if you have a lot of bullets that share the same curves data, since you can assign the same resource to all of them instead of creating a new one for each bullet.
